newsitem.title: USA: U.S. 30-year bond down more than full point.
newsitem.headline: U.S. 30-year bond down more than full point.

text.p: The benchmark U.S. 30-year bond was off more than a full point at 94-18/32 to yield 7.07 percent in technicals-driven trade, analysts said.
"A lot of it is dealer selling more than anything else," said Matthey Alexy, chief market strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston. "The technicals are pretty ugly."
The selloff began after Thursday morning's economic data and continued as the bond yield held above 7.0 percent, which had been seen by many as a key support level.
The data showed existing home sales grew swiftly in February and help wanted advertising picked up as well.
Reported comments by former Federal Reserve officials Lyle Gramley and Alan Blinder that additional rate hikes were likely in order to slow the economy were not seen as a large factor in the selloff.
